awd_titl_txt: CC-NIE Integration: Improved Infrastructure for Data Movement and Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops an infrastructure to support managing the transfer and analysis of big data as required by several projects at the University of California at Davis. For example, the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) Project will soon produce 30 terabytes of data each night. Scientists at UC Davis examine the data, testing new search and analysis algorithms to find new or unexpected phenomena. This collaborative project requires high-speed connections to the other 22 institutions involved in the project. Similarly, the Genome project and other projects benefit, or will shortly benefit, from the changes being made to the internal networking infrastructure. 

The project also provides data for campus research groups that study networks. For example, the Robust and Ubiquitous Networking Laboratory and the Computer Security Laboratory use network traffic and performance measurements in their research, and the enhancements to the network enable them to gather this data in ways that do not violate University privacy regulations. Further, the network architecture enables administrative staff to deploy enhanced monitoring capabilities to detect network traffic problems. Support personnel including undergraduates act as a bridge between the research projects using this enhanced network and the network managers, so researchers can obtain the optimum network performance that they need, and the network itself can be tuned as appropriate to minimize overhead.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to redesign the research network at UC Davis to provide the research projects with the connections (and other network support) that they need. Further, the architecture of the network is flexible and expandable, so as new projects come on line, the network can be adapted to handle their needs, too. The network architecture also provides enhanced monitoring capabilities to support performance measurements and the ability to experiment with other capabilities (notably, OpenFlow support will enable experiments with routing).

This project enabled UC Davis to establish a state-of-the-art network dedicated to research that provided much higher speed connections with the Internet than the regular production network. It also allowed UC Davis to upgrade its connection to our regional network provider. The research network infrastructure was augmented with mechanisms to test the network and measure performance so the network could be tuned to provide maximum throughput to the projects.

In addition, UC Davis established a testbed in the research network for software-defined networking, which provides for more flexible network management than traditional networking. This testbed allows Communications Resources, which manages the network, and faculty and students to develop expertise in that technology, as well as support research into software-defined networking.

This project benefitted several current research projects.

In engineering, the measurement and monitoring capabilities architected into the new research network provided the facilities to support networking research. The Robust and Ubiquitous Networking Laboratory's project to design algorithms to improve the ability to measure performance (in terms of both accuracy and delay) under a variety of conditions made extensive use of the software-defined networking testbed as well as equipment in that Laboratory. As a result, they were able to design and validate algorithms to learn and identify the flows to be monitored. As another example, the Computer Security Laboratory has made use of the improved monitoring facilities to gather traffic to study the effect of data sanitization upon detecting attacks over the network. A related project, the NetSage Project, is using performance data gathered from the research network to develop a network measurement, analysis, and visualization service.

In the sciences, the faculty and staff at UC Davis are engaged in several very large projects that involve managing and analyzing massive amounts of data. For example, the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) Project, sponsored by the NSF, DoE, IN2P3 in France, and a number of private donations, will produce 30 terabytes of data each night. Scientists at UC Davis will examine the data testing new search and analysis algorithms to find new or unexpected phenomena. This collaborative project will require high-speed connections to the other 22 institutions involved in the project. The new research network upgraded the internal campus network to be able to support the LSST networking requirements. In geology, the network has assisted the transfer of large amounts of data used for visualization of geologic phenomena.

Given the wide diversity of research projects at UC Davis, this project has had, and will continue to have, broad impact on research conducted in a variety of disciplines.
